SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name ...........................................

2. Your address ...........................................

3. Date ......................................................

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Greenwich, Kent, England

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Contractor / Henry Latham Butcher

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   March 1904

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
   In England only ( Worthing, Sussex; Petworth, Sussex )

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   30 years

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   I wanted to see the new country of which I had read much.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    The Press- and Canadian Government publications.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Many approved - some thought it foolish.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

With my father, mother and six sisters. (Two brothers had come a year previously - and wrote glowingly about Canada.)

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Allan Steamship to Canada - Canadian Pacific Railway in Canada.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.).

Terrific snowstorm that held us 52 hours in Whitewood - in our train - March 1904 - we were told that there were nine trains snowbound between Whitewood and Regina. Nothing else at all special., except perhaps that the Conductor stopped to look down on our nine passengers and said (with a nice smile) "I suppose you folks think you are coming to a nice country - well it is like this for nine months of the year, but the other three months are hot too bad". He was a particularly nice conductor.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Wolseley, for about a year.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

In the Touchwood Hills - 12 miles east of what is now Punnichy.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

4 years on the homestead in Touchwood Hills, then in the new village of Punnichy to this date, except for a few months in Ottawa.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Before: General Store; after: odd jobs for one year, then homesteading with occasional odd jobs to make a few dollars. In 1908 came to the new village of Punnichy, implement business for one year, then insurance agent, etc. for several years, and finally law student - and (in 1926) lawyer. Since that date the same.
Butcher, Harry
Punnichy.

To Sask. - March, 1904

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Canada?
Many approved - some thought it foolish.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
With my father, mother and six sisters. (Two brothers had come a year previously - and wrote glowingy about Canada.)

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Allian Steamship to Canada - Canadian Pacific Railway in Canada.

14. What incidents of the journey most do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, difficulties on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)
Traveling snow storm that held us 52 hours in Whitecourt - In our train - March 1904 - we were told that there were nothing else at all special; except perhaps that the conductor stopped at all stations except on our line. Passengers and said (with a nice smile) "I suppose you folks think you're coming to a nice country - well it's like this for nine months of the year, but the other three months are not too bad." He was a particularly nice conductor.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
Wolsley - for about a year.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
In the Touchwood Hills - 12 miles east of what is now.

17. Mention anything placed where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.
In the new village of Punnichy to this date, except for a few months in Ottawa.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
General store: After jobs for our year, then housekeeping came to the new Village of Punnichy, implementing business for one year, then insurance agent etc. for several years, and finally law student - and (in 1920) lawyer. Since first date the same.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

Repeatedly - and still correspond with four friends in England (regularly)

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Never married.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

Several people - probably twelve

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

Parents lived with me till their death.
Two brothers moved to West Coast.
Five sisters have married and live in Saskatchewan or B.C.
One sister (invalid) still lives in my home.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

Very little.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, how many?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience or pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to recount?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   I believe it was in 1911

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   1914 - Ford Car.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   For the first four years, when on the homesteads, it was Lipton - a journey of fifty miles. Later Punnichy 12 miles from the homestead.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   For four years only, later at Punnichy, 12 miles from the homestead. I moved into Punnichy with most of my people in 1908, just as the Grand Trunk Pacific came through.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Fortnightly - travelling with neighbours at times.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   From the first days on the homestead (1905) until stores were opened in Punnichy. We have always tried to trade locally from that time. Perhaps five per cent of purchases in Dry Goods have since been made from T.Eaton Company.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   The first telephone in this district was built by me from my Punnichy home to a home in which my parents lived - about six hundred yards. The Government phones came later.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   I made up my mind to stay permanently - if possible. And it was possible.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   I believe it was in 1911.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading centre? How far from your house?
   For the first four years, when on the homestead, it was Lipton. - a journey of thirty miles. Later Punichy.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   For four years only - later at Punichy, 12 miles from the homestead, or 30 miles into Punichy with most of my people in 1908; just as the Grand Trunk Pacific came through.

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Fortnightly - travelling with neighbours at times.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. Then (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogue?
   That kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order either the pioneer period or present day.

From the first days on the homestead (1905) until stores were opened in Punichy, we have always tried to trade locally from that time. Perhaps five per cent of purchases in dry goods have since been made from T. Scott Company.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it? This district was built by me from my property's hiding to a home in Punichy. We lived there.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision? Or did you make up my mind to stay permanently - if possible? And it was possible.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1904? What reasons did they have for moving?

Very few - reason unknown.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

No! On the other hand people came in from South Saskatchewan.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Chairman of First School District erected - Westmoor School @ I think in 1910. Councillor in R.M.Kutawa for few years. Chairman of Punnichy Village School Board for a few years. M.P. for Last Mountain from 1930-1935 - then Constituency abolished in Redistribution.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.).

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in name since the first name was given date and reason for change. Give facts in neat name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Punnichy Village was named after the first trader in the district - Mr. Heubach, who was quite a young man when he came to Kutawa (which is about five miles from Punnichy). The story is that the Indians of the district promptly named him "Punnichy" which is said to be Indian for "newly fledged chicken" in honour of a few sandy hairs on his upper lip." The site selected for the Village was selected before the railway had reached it, and it is said it was so selected on the suggestion of Mr. Heubach, and as a result of an evening spent with him by Mr. Morse, then Vice-President of the Grand Trunk Pacific (Western) - so it alleged.

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Unfortunately I have not.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

(Am not married)

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

A continual but slow development. When I settled in this village there were three buildings. Now there are eight blocks reasonably well settled.
